We would party all day long. We would get
high. We would get drunk. And at the same

6.text:
time we would have to watch out for people
being shot at. We just tried to stay

10.text:
alive. I grew up in Los Angeles, California,
where the gang life was part of the everyday

16.text:
swing of things. And I would watch all the
older gang members get high or drunk, or come

21.text:
to the house and party. I remember they would
feed me, uh, take care of me, and eventually

26.text:
I developed, like, a love for them that I
wanted to please them. As I got into about

31.text:
12 or 13 years old, it became a sense of honor
to belong to a gang. When people saw me they

36.text:
didn't just see me as an individual. They
saw the status of my gang. And so they started

41.text:
to fear me, they would respect me, uh, and
it was the gang life that ripped our family

45.text:
apart. My oldest brother, at the age of 15,
was murdered, uh, by a gang member. I was

52.text:
shot at the age of 14 years old in a gang-related
shooting. It really set our family on the

57.text:
track to hit the streets hard. I was filled
with anger. All I could think about was revenge.

65.text:
I skipped school one day and we went cruisin'
around. And we saw some gang graffiti on the

70.text:
wall from our rival gang members. And so,
we said to ourself, "let's go spray paint

74.text:
on the wall. Let's disrespect them." So we
left to go get a can of spray paint, and by

78.text:
the time we came back there was gang members
on the street. But we changed our minds. We

82.text:
said it was too dangerous to get out of the
car. As I was driving away, the question was

87.text:
posed, "Should we shoot at them?" I responded,
"Yeah." So we took off. And I didn't know

97.text:
if somebody got hit, I didn't know if somebody
died. Yeah, the next morning I woke up to

102.text:
banging on my door. I thought it was my grandma
waking me up to go to school. But it wasn't.

106.text:
It was the Sheriff's Department. They banged
on the door, told me to get down, they put

111.text:
their gun to my head, they handcuffed me and
escorted me through the living room. I can

115.text:
still remember seeing my grandma sitting down
in the corner with tears in her eyes as she

120.text:
cried out, "What did you do? What did you
do?" I didn't know how to respond so I put

127.text:
my head down and I continued to walk out the
house. They put me in the back of the cop

131.text:
car and they begin to drive off. The detective,
he turned around and he told me, "You better

137.text:
take a good look at them streets, boy, because
you'll never see them again." I looked at

144.text:
the people going to school or to work, and
for them it was the start of another normal

148.text:
day. But for me, it was the beginning of the
end. They took me to the police station, they

156.text:
booked me for one murder and one attempted
murder. And about a year later at the age

161.text:
of 17 years old in the Compton Courthouse,
the judge sentenced me to prison for life.

166.text:
But this time they put me in a one-man cell
in the L.A. County Jail. It was over. My future

174.text:
was gone. I had sacrificed myself for my gang.
It was like I was dead but I was still alive.

180.text:
I was crushed by despair and hopelessness.
I remember being in my one-man cell, and my

186.text:
face was pressed against my knees because
I realized I was never gonna be a husband,

191.text:
I was never gonna be a father. And all of
a sudden I began to regret that I didn't listen

196.text:
to my parents, that I didn't go home when
I should have went home. I was regretting that

200.text:
I only lived 16 years and it was over. I was
regretting that I would die a slow death in

206.text:
prison. As I sat there in my one-man cell,
I heard a noise in the hallway. And I got

212.text:
up and I put my face against the bars. And
I looked and it was an elderly man passing

217.text:
out, uh, Christian literature. And I was still
mad at the world. I didn't want to talk to

221.text:
anybody. But this old man, he kind of barged
into my darkness. He stood there and he did

227.text:
something I'll never forget. He had the courage
to reach through the darkness of my bars.

232.text:
He grabbed my hand, and he said a quiet prayer
over me in the Name of Jesus Christ. It was

239.text:
like God's compassion exploding in the darkest
moment, uh, of my life. I didn't feel alone.

246.text:
I felt that God reached out to me. I got down
on my knees, and as a broken teenager I cried

252.text:
out to God. It wasn't even a prayer. It was
a groan, uh, from the depths of my heart.

258.text:
And not too long after that God gave me a
vision. And He said, "Brian, if you serve

263.text:
me and don't give up, eventually I'll release
you from this life sentence to impact the

268.text:
world with the gospel." God sent other people
into my life to help mentor me and disciple

274.text:
me in the Word of God. And God began to restore
my life. At the same time, I married my childhood

280.text:
sweetheart. And my wife began to fight for
my freedom. The governor had said no lifer,

286.text:
uh, will be paroled except in a pine box.
I was denied parole 5 times by the California

292.text:
governors. I actually came to a place in my
walk where I told God, "It doesn't matter

297.text:
no more. If I go home or if I die in prison,
I'm gonna serve you no matter what." About

303.text:
a year after I made that commitment, after
16 years in the darkness of prison I walked

308.text:
out a free man and restored to my family.
I'm amazed how God has turned my story around.

318.text:
I don't deserve to be looking at this blue
sky. I deserve death. But by the grace of

323.text:
God today I'm a father, I'm a husband, today
I get the awesome privilege of pastoring a,

329.text:
an awesome church that is impacting hundreds
and thousands of lives. And I'm just grateful

334.text:
for every breath I take out here. He brought
this broken, 16-year old boy from hopelessness

342.text:
to a life of hope and a life of purpose. I'm
able to lift up my head now because of the

347.text:
forgiveness and freedom that I have in Jesus.
My past no longer haunts me. God set me free.
